trans-unit.source: Common startup tasks for Cloud Services | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Common startup tasks for Cloud Services | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Provides some examples of common startup tasks you may want to perform in your cloud services web role or worker role.
trans-unit.target: Provides some examples of common startup tasks you may want to perform in your cloud services web role or worker role.

trans-unit.source: This article provides some examples of common startup tasks you may want to perform in your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: This article provides some examples of common startup tasks you may want to perform in your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: You can use startup tasks to perform operations before a role starts.
trans-unit.target: You can use startup tasks to perform operations before a role starts.

trans-unit.source: Operations that you might want to perform include installing a component, registering COM components, setting registry keys, or starting a long running process.
trans-unit.target: Operations that you might want to perform include installing a component, registering COM components, setting registry keys, or starting a long running process.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>this article</linkText><title></title> to understand how startup tasks work, and specifically how to create the entries that define a startup task.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>this article</linkText><title></title> to understand how startup tasks work, and specifically how to create the entries that define a startup task.

trans-unit.source: Many of the tasks here use the
trans-unit.target: Many of the tasks here use the

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks are not applicable to Virtual Machines, only to Cloud Service Web and Worker roles.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks are not applicable to Virtual Machines, only to Cloud Service Web and Worker roles.

trans-unit.source: You can define environment variables for an entire role by adding the [Runtime] element to the definition of the role in the service definition file.
trans-unit.target: You can define environment variables for an entire role by adding the [Runtime] element to the definition of the role in the service definition file.

trans-unit.source: If you need environment variables defined for a specific task, that isn't shared by other tasks, you can use the [Environment] element inside of the [Task] element.
trans-unit.target: If you need environment variables defined for a specific task, that isn't shared by other tasks, you can use the [Environment] element inside of the [Task] element.

trans-unit.source: Variables can also use a <linkText>valid Azure XPath value</linkText><title></title> to reference something about the deployment.
trans-unit.target: Variables can also use a <linkText>valid Azure XPath value</linkText><title></title> to reference something about the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Instead of using the value attribute, define a [RoleInstanceValue] child element.
trans-unit.target: Instead of using the value attribute, define a [RoleInstanceValue] child element.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>AppCmd.exe</linkText><title></title> command line tool can be used to manage IIS settings at startup on Azure.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>AppCmd.exe</linkText><title></title> command line tool can be used to manage IIS settings at startup on Azure.

trans-unit.source: AppCmd.exe provides convenient, command line access to configuration settings for use in startup tasks on Azure.
trans-unit.target: AppCmd.exe provides convenient, command line access to configuration settings for use in startup tasks on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Using AppCmd.exe, Website settings can be added, modified, or removed for applications and sites.
trans-unit.target: Using AppCmd.exe, Website settings can be added, modified, or removed for applications and sites.

trans-unit.source: However, there are a few things to watch out for in the use of AppCmd.exe as a startup task:
trans-unit.target: However, there are a few things to watch out for in the use of AppCmd.exe as a startup task:

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks can be run more than once between reboots.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks can be run more than once between reboots.

trans-unit.source: This can happen if the role recycles, for instance.
trans-unit.target: This can happen if the role recycles, for instance.

trans-unit.source: Some AppCmd.exe actions can generate errors if they are performed more than once.
trans-unit.target: Some AppCmd.exe actions can generate errors if they are performed more than once.

trans-unit.source: Attempting to add a section to Web.config twice could generate an error.
trans-unit.target: Attempting to add a section to Web.config twice could generate an error.

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks fail if they return a non-zero exit code or errorlevel.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks fail if they return a non-zero exit code or errorlevel.

trans-unit.source: This can happen if AppCmd.exe generates an error.
trans-unit.target: This can happen if AppCmd.exe generates an error.

trans-unit.source: For the reasons listed, it is often wise to check the errorlevel after calling AppCmd.exe, which is easy to do if you wrap the call to AppCmd.exe with a .cmd file.
trans-unit.target: For the reasons listed, it is often wise to check the errorlevel after calling AppCmd.exe, which is easy to do if you wrap the call to AppCmd.exe with a .cmd file.

trans-unit.source: If you detect a known errorlevel response, you can ignore it, otherwise return it.
trans-unit.target: If you detect a known errorlevel response, you can ignore it, otherwise return it.

trans-unit.source: This is demonstrated in the example below.
trans-unit.target: This is demonstrated in the example below.

trans-unit.source: The errorlevels returned by AppCmd.exe are listed in the winerror.h file, and can also be seen on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: The errorlevels returned by AppCmd.exe are listed in the winerror.h file, and can also be seen on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: This example adds a compression section and a compression entry for JSON to the Web.config file, with error handling and logging.
trans-unit.target: This example adds a compression section and a compression entry for JSON to the Web.config file, with error handling and logging.

trans-unit.source: The relevant sections of the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file are shown here, which include setting the executionContext attribute to elevated to give AppCmd.exe sufficient permissions to change the settings in the Web.config file:
trans-unit.target: The relevant sections of the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file are shown here, which include setting the executionContext attribute to elevated to give AppCmd.exe sufficient permissions to change the settings in the Web.config file:

trans-unit.source: The Startup.cmd batch file uses AppCmd.exe to add a compression section and a compression entry for JSON to the Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: The Startup.cmd batch file uses AppCmd.exe to add a compression section and a compression entry for JSON to the Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: The expected errorlevel of 183 is set to zero using the VERIFY.EXE command line program.
trans-unit.target: The expected errorlevel of 183 is set to zero using the VERIFY.EXE command line program.

trans-unit.source: Unexpected errorlevels are logged to StartupErrorLog.txt.
trans-unit.target: Unexpected errorlevels are logged to StartupErrorLog.txt.

trans-unit.source: In Azure, there are effectively two firewalls.
trans-unit.target: In Azure, there are effectively two firewalls.

trans-unit.source: The first firewall controls connections between the virtual machine and the outside world.
trans-unit.target: The first firewall controls connections between the virtual machine and the outside world.

trans-unit.source: This is controlled by the [EndPoints] element in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file.
trans-unit.target: This is controlled by the [EndPoints] element in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file.

trans-unit.source: The second firewall controls connections between the virtual machine and the processes within that virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The second firewall controls connections between the virtual machine and the processes within that virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: This is controlled by the netsh advfirewall firewall command line tool, and is the focus of this article.
trans-unit.target: This is controlled by the netsh advfirewall firewall command line tool, and is the focus of this article.

trans-unit.source: Azure creates firewall rules for the processes started within your roles.
trans-unit.target: Azure creates firewall rules for the processes started within your roles.

trans-unit.source: For example, when you start a service or program, Azure automatically creates the necessary firewall rules to allow that service to communicate with the Internet.
trans-unit.target: For example, when you start a service or program, Azure automatically creates the necessary firewall rules to allow that service to communicate with the Internet.

trans-unit.source: However, if you create a service that is started by a process outside your role (for example, a COM+ service, or a program that starts by using the Windows Scheduler), you will need to manually create a firewall rule to allow access to that service.
trans-unit.target: However, if you create a service that is started by a process outside your role (for example, a COM+ service, or a program that starts by using the Windows Scheduler), you will need to manually create a firewall rule to allow access to that service.

trans-unit.source: These firewall rules can be created by using a startup task.
trans-unit.target: These firewall rules can be created by using a startup task.

trans-unit.source: A startup task that creates a firewall rule must have an executionContext[task] of elevated.
trans-unit.target: A startup task that creates a firewall rule must have an executionContext[task] of elevated.

trans-unit.source: Add the following startup task to the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file.
trans-unit.target: Add the following startup task to the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file.

trans-unit.source: To add the firewall rule, you must use the appropriate netsh advfirewall firewall commands in your startup batch file.
trans-unit.target: To add the firewall rule, you must use the appropriate netsh advfirewall firewall commands in your startup batch file.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the startup task requires security and encryption for TCP port 80.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the startup task requires security and encryption for TCP port 80.

trans-unit.source: You can restrict an Azure web role access to a set of specified IP addresses by modifying your IIS web.config file and creating a command file which unlocks the ipSecurity section of the ApplicationHost.config file.
trans-unit.target: You can restrict an Azure web role access to a set of specified IP addresses by modifying your IIS web.config file and creating a command file which unlocks the ipSecurity section of the ApplicationHost.config file.

trans-unit.source: First, create a command file that runs when your role starts which unlocks the ipSecurity section of the ApplicationHost.config file.
trans-unit.target: First, create a command file that runs when your role starts which unlocks the ipSecurity section of the ApplicationHost.config file.

trans-unit.source: Create a new folder at the root level of your web role called startup and, within this folder, create a batch file called startup.cmd.
trans-unit.target: Create a new folder at the root level of your web role called startup and, within this folder, create a batch file called startup.cmd.

trans-unit.source: Set the properties of this file to Copy Always to ensure that it will be deployed.
trans-unit.target: Set the properties of this file to Copy Always to ensure that it will be deployed.

trans-unit.source: Add the following startup task to the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file.
trans-unit.target: Add the following startup task to the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file.

trans-unit.source: Add this command to the startup.cmd file:
trans-unit.target: Add this command to the startup.cmd file:

trans-unit.source: This causes the startup.cmd batch file to be run every time the web role is initialized, ensuring that the required ipSecurity section is unlocked.
trans-unit.target: This causes the startup.cmd batch file to be run every time the web role is initialized, ensuring that the required ipSecurity section is unlocked.

trans-unit.source: Finally, modify the system.webServer section your web role’s web.config file to add a list of IP addresses that are granted access, as shown in the following example:
trans-unit.target: Finally, modify the system.webServer section your web role’s web.config file to add a list of IP addresses that are granted access, as shown in the following example:

trans-unit.source: This sample config allows all IPs to access the server except the two defined
trans-unit.target: This sample config allows all IPs to access the server except the two defined

trans-unit.source: This sample config denies all IPs from accessing the server except for the two defined.
trans-unit.target: This sample config denies all IPs from accessing the server except for the two defined.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell scripts cannot be called directly from the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file, but they can be invoked from within a startup batch file.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell scripts cannot be called directly from the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file, but they can be invoked from within a startup batch file.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell, by default, will not run an unsigned script.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell, by default, will not run an unsigned script.

trans-unit.source: Unless you sign your scripts, you need to configure Windows PowerShell to run unsigned scripts.
trans-unit.target: Unless you sign your scripts, you need to configure Windows PowerShell to run unsigned scripts.

trans-unit.source: To run unsigned scripts, ExecutionPolicy must be set to Unrestricted.
trans-unit.target: To run unsigned scripts, ExecutionPolicy must be set to Unrestricted.

trans-unit.source: The ExecutionPolicy setting that you use is based on the version of Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The ExecutionPolicy setting that you use is based on the version of Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: If you're using a Guest OS that is runs PowerShell 2.0 or 1.0 you can force version 2 to run, and if unavailable, use version 1.
trans-unit.target: If you're using a Guest OS that is runs PowerShell 2.0 or 1.0 you can force version 2 to run, and if unavailable, use version 1.

trans-unit.source: You can use a local storage resource to store files created by your startup task which will be accessed later by your application.
trans-unit.target: You can use a local storage resource to store files created by your startup task which will be accessed later by your application.

trans-unit.source: To create the local storage resource, add a [LocalResources] section to the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file and then add the [LocalStorage] child element.
trans-unit.target: To create the local storage resource, add a [LocalResources] section to the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file and then add the [LocalStorage] child element.

trans-unit.source: Give the local storage resource a unique name and an appropriate size for your startup task.
trans-unit.target: Give the local storage resource a unique name and an appropriate size for your startup task.

trans-unit.source: To use a local storage resource in your startup task, you need to create an environment variable to reference the local storage resource location.
trans-unit.target: To use a local storage resource in your startup task, you need to create an environment variable to reference the local storage resource location.

trans-unit.source: Then the Startup task and the application will be able to read and write files to the local storage resource.
trans-unit.target: Then the Startup task and the application will be able to read and write files to the local storage resource.

trans-unit.source: The relevant sections of the ServiceDefinition.csdef file are shown here:
trans-unit.target: The relevant sections of the ServiceDefinition.csdef file are shown here:

trans-unit.source: As an example, this Startup.cmd batch file uses the PathToStartupStorage environment variable to create the file MyTest.txt on the local storage location.
trans-unit.target: As an example, this Startup.cmd batch file uses the PathToStartupStorage environment variable to create the file MyTest.txt on the local storage location.

trans-unit.source: You can access local storage from the Azure SDK by using the <linkText>GetLocalResource</linkText><title></title> method.
trans-unit.target: You can access local storage from the Azure SDK by using the <linkText>GetLocalResource</linkText><title></title> method.

trans-unit.source: Standard file read and write operations will then work to read and write the contents of the local storage resource.
trans-unit.target: Standard file read and write operations will then work to read and write the contents of the local storage resource.

trans-unit.source: You can have your startup task perform different steps when it is operating in the cloud compared to when it is in the compute emulator.
trans-unit.target: You can have your startup task perform different steps when it is operating in the cloud compared to when it is in the compute emulator.

trans-unit.source: For example, you may want to use a fresh copy of your SQL data only when running in the emulator.
trans-unit.target: For example, you may want to use a fresh copy of your SQL data only when running in the emulator.

trans-unit.source: Or you may want to do some sort of performance optimizations for the cloud that you don't need to do when running in the emulator.
trans-unit.target: Or you may want to do some sort of performance optimizations for the cloud that you don't need to do when running in the emulator.

trans-unit.source: This ability to perform different actions on the compute emulator and the cloud can be accomplished by creating an environment variable in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file, then testing the environment variable in your startup task.
trans-unit.target: This ability to perform different actions on the compute emulator and the cloud can be accomplished by creating an environment variable in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file, then testing the environment variable in your startup task.

trans-unit.source: To create the environment variable, add the [Variable]/[RoleInstanceValue] element and create an XPath value of /RoleEnvironment/Deployment/@emulated.
trans-unit.target: To create the environment variable, add the [Variable]/[RoleInstanceValue] element and create an XPath value of /RoleEnvironment/Deployment/@emulated.

trans-unit.source: The value of the %ComputeEmulatorRunning% environment variable will be "true" when running on the compute emulator, and "false" when running on the cloud.
trans-unit.target: The value of the %ComputeEmulatorRunning% environment variable will be "true" when running on the compute emulator, and "false" when running on the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Any task run can now use the %ComputeEmulatorRunning% environment variable to perform different actions based on whether or not the role is running in the cloud or the emulator.
trans-unit.target: Any task run can now use the %ComputeEmulatorRunning% environment variable to perform different actions based on whether or not the role is running in the cloud or the emulator.

trans-unit.source: Here is a .cmd shell script that checks for that environment variable.
trans-unit.target: Here is a .cmd shell script that checks for that environment variable.

trans-unit.source: The role may recycle without a reboot causing your startup tasks to run again.
trans-unit.target: The role may recycle without a reboot causing your startup tasks to run again.

trans-unit.source: There is flag to indicate a task has already run on the hosting VM.
trans-unit.target: There is flag to indicate a task has already run on the hosting VM.

trans-unit.source: You may have some tasks where it doesn't matter that they run multiple times.
trans-unit.target: You may have some tasks where it doesn't matter that they run multiple times.

trans-unit.source: However you may run into a situation where you need to prevent a task from running more than once.
trans-unit.target: However you may run into a situation where you need to prevent a task from running more than once.

trans-unit.source: The simplest way to detect that a task has already run is to create a file in the %TEMP% folder when the task is successful and look for it at the start of the task.
trans-unit.target: The simplest way to detect that a task has already run is to create a file in the %TEMP% folder when the task is successful and look for it at the start of the task.

trans-unit.source: Here is a sample cmd shell script that does that for you.
trans-unit.target: Here is a sample cmd shell script that does that for you.

trans-unit.source: Here are some best practices you should follow when configuring task for your web or worker role.
trans-unit.target: Here are some best practices you should follow when configuring task for your web or worker role.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio does not provide a debugger to step through batch files, so it's good to get as much data on the operation of batch files as possible. Logging the output of batch files, both stdout and stderr, can give you important information when trying to debug and fix batch files. To log both stdout and stderr to the StartupLog.txt file in the directory pointed to by the %TEMP% environment variable, add the text >> "%TEMP%\\StartupLog.txt" 2>&1 to the end of specific lines you want to log. For example, to execute setup.exe in the %PathToApp1Install% directory:
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio does not provide a debugger to step through batch files, so it's good to get as much data on the operation of batch files as possible. Logging the output of batch files, both stdout and stderr, can give you important information when trying to debug and fix batch files. To log both stdout and stderr to the StartupLog.txt file in the directory pointed to by the %TEMP% environment variable, add the text >> "%TEMP%\\StartupLog.txt" 2>&1 to the end of specific lines you want to log. For example, to execute setup.exe in the %PathToApp1Install% directory:

trans-unit.source: If you want to log all output from the startup task without adding >> "%TEMP%\StartupLog.txt" 2>&1to the end of each line, two startup batch files are needed. The first batch file will call the second batch file with redirection to log all of the activities of the second batch file. This is necessary for proper redirection to occur.
trans-unit.target: If you want to log all output from the startup task without adding >> "%TEMP%\StartupLog.txt" 2>&1to the end of each line, two startup batch files are needed. The first batch file will call the second batch file with redirection to log all of the activities of the second batch file. This is necessary for proper redirection to occur.

trans-unit.source: The following shows how to redirect all output from a startup batch file.
trans-unit.target: The following shows how to redirect all output from a startup batch file.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the ServerDefinition.csdef file creates a startup task that calls Startup1.cmd.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the ServerDefinition.csdef file creates a startup task that calls Startup1.cmd.

trans-unit.source: Startup1.cmd calls Startup2.cmd, redirecting all output to %TEMP%\\StartupLog.txt.
trans-unit.target: Startup1.cmd calls Startup2.cmd, redirecting all output to %TEMP%\\StartupLog.txt.

trans-unit.source: ServiceDefinition.cmd:
trans-unit.target: ServiceDefinition.cmd:

trans-unit.source: Startup1.cmd:
trans-unit.target: Startup1.cmd:

trans-unit.source: Startup2.cmd:
trans-unit.target: Startup2.cmd:

trans-unit.source: Set privileges appropriately for the startup task.
trans-unit.target: Set privileges appropriately for the startup task.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes startup tasks must run with elevated privileges even though the role runs with normal privileges.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes startup tasks must run with elevated privileges even though the role runs with normal privileges.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>executionContext[task]</linkText><title></title> attribute sets the privilege level of the startup task.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>executionContext[task]</linkText><title></title> attribute sets the privilege level of the startup task.

trans-unit.source: Using executionContext="limited" means the startup task will have the same privilege level as the role.
trans-unit.target: Using executionContext="limited" means the startup task will have the same privilege level as the role.

trans-unit.source: Using executionContext="elevated" means the startup task will have administrator privileges, which allows the startup task to perform administrator tasks without giving administrator privileges to your role.
trans-unit.target: Using executionContext="elevated" means the startup task will have administrator privileges, which allows the startup task to perform administrator tasks without giving administrator privileges to your role.

trans-unit.source: An example of a startup task that requires elevated privileges is a startup task that uses AppCmd.exe to configure IIS.
trans-unit.target: An example of a startup task that requires elevated privileges is a startup task that uses AppCmd.exe to configure IIS.

trans-unit.source: AppCmd.exe requires executionContext="elevated".
trans-unit.target: AppCmd.exe requires executionContext="elevated".

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>taskType[task]</linkText><title></title> attribute determines the way the startup task will be executed.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>taskType[task]</linkText><title></title> attribute determines the way the startup task will be executed.

trans-unit.source: There are three values: simple, background, and foreground.
trans-unit.target: There are three values: simple, background, and foreground.

trans-unit.source: The background and foreground tasks are started asynchronously, and then the simple tasks are executed synchronously one at a time.
trans-unit.target: The background and foreground tasks are started asynchronously, and then the simple tasks are executed synchronously one at a time.

trans-unit.source: With simple startup tasks, you can set the order in which the tasks will occur by the order in which the tasks are listed in the ServiceDefinition.csdef file.
trans-unit.target: With simple startup tasks, you can set the order in which the tasks will occur by the order in which the tasks are listed in the ServiceDefinition.csdef file.

trans-unit.source: If a simple task ends with a non-zero exit code, then the startup procedure will stop and the role will not start.
trans-unit.target: If a simple task ends with a non-zero exit code, then the startup procedure will stop and the role will not start.

trans-unit.source: The difference between background startup tasks and foreground startup tasks is that foreground tasks will keep the role running until the foreground task ends.
trans-unit.target: The difference between background startup tasks and foreground startup tasks is that foreground tasks will keep the role running until the foreground task ends.

trans-unit.source: This also means that if the foreground task hangs or crashes, the role will not recycle until the foreground task is forced closed.
trans-unit.target: This also means that if the foreground task hangs or crashes, the role will not recycle until the foreground task is forced closed.

trans-unit.source: For this reason, background tasks are recommended for asynchronous startup tasks unless you need that feature of the foreground task.
trans-unit.target: For this reason, background tasks are recommended for asynchronous startup tasks unless you need that feature of the foreground task.

trans-unit.source: The role will only start if the errorlevel from each of your simple startup task is zero.
trans-unit.target: The role will only start if the errorlevel from each of your simple startup task is zero.

trans-unit.source: Not all programs set the errorlevel (exit code) correctly, so the batch file should end with an EXIT /B 0 if everything ran correctly.
trans-unit.target: Not all programs set the errorlevel (exit code) correctly, so the batch file should end with an EXIT /B 0 if everything ran correctly.

trans-unit.source: A missing EXIT /B 0 at the end of a startup batch file is a common cause of roles that do not start.
trans-unit.target: A missing EXIT /B 0 at the end of a startup batch file is a common cause of roles that do not start.

trans-unit.source: Not all role recycles include a reboot, but all role recycles include running all startup tasks.
trans-unit.target: Not all role recycles include a reboot, but all role recycles include running all startup tasks.

trans-unit.source: This means that startup tasks must be able to run multiple times between reboots without any problems.
trans-unit.target: This means that startup tasks must be able to run multiple times between reboots without any problems.

trans-unit.source: This is discussed <linkText>above</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This is discussed <linkText>above</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to copy or create a file during your startup task that is then accessible to your role, then that file must be placed in local storage.
trans-unit.target: If you want to copy or create a file during your startup task that is then accessible to your role, then that file must be placed in local storage.

trans-unit.source: See the <linkText>section</linkText><title></title> above.
trans-unit.target: See the <linkText>section</linkText><title></title> above.

trans-unit.source: Review the cloud <linkText>service model and package</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Review the cloud <linkText>service model and package</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: Learn more about how <linkText>Tasks</linkText><title></title> work.

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create and deploy</linkText><title></title> your cloud service package.
